tips.name: Care About Your Craft
tips.text: Why spend your life developing software unless you care about doing it well?

tips.name: Think! About Your Work
tips.text: Turn off the autopilot and take control. Constantly critique and appraise your work.

tips.name: Provide Options, Don't Make Lame Excuses
tips.text: Instead of excuses, provide options. Don't say it can't be done; explain what can be done.

tips.name: Don't Live with Broken Windows
tips.text: Fix bad designs, wrong decisions, and poor code when you see them.

tips.name: Be a Catalyst for Change
tips.text: You can't force change on people. Instead, show them how the future might be and help them participate in creating it.

tips.name: Remember the Big Picture
tips.text: Don't get so engrossed in the details that you forget to check what's happening around you.

tips.name: Make Quality a Requirements Issue
tips.text: Involve your users in determining the project's real quality requirements.

tips.name: Invest Regularly in Your Knowledge Portfolio
tips.text: Make learning a habit.

tips.name: Critically Analyze What You Read and Hear
tips.text: Don't be swayed by vendors, media hype, or dogma. Analyze information in terms of you and your project.

tips.name: It's Both What You Say and the Way You Say It
tips.text: There's no point in having great ideas if you don't communicate them effectively.

tips.name: DRY - Don't Repeat Yourself
tips.text: Every piece of knowledge must have a single, unambiguous, authoritative representation within a system.

tips.name: Make It Easy to Reuse
tips.text: If it's easy to reuse, people will. Create an environment that supports reuse.

tips.name: Eliminate Effects Between Unrelated Things
tips.text: Design components that are self-contained. independent, and have a single, well-defined purpose.

tips.name: There Are No Final Decisions
tips.text: No decision is cast in stone. Instead, consider each as being written in the sand at the beach, and plan for change.

tips.name: Use Tracer Bullets to Find the Target
tips.text: Tracer bullets let you home in on your target by trying things and seeing how close they land.

tips.name: Prototype to Learn
tips.text: Prototyping is a learning experience. Its value lies not in the code you produce, but in the lessons you learn.

tips.name: Program Close to the Problem Domain
tips.text: Design and code in your user's language.

tips.name: Estimate to Avoid Surprises
tips.text: Estimate before you start. You'll spot potential problems up front.

tips.name: Iterate the Schedule with the Code
tips.text: Use experience you gain as you implement to refine the project time scales.

tips.name: Keep Knowledge in Plain Text
tips.text: Plain text won't become obsolete. It helps leverage your work and simplifies debugging and testing.

tips.name: Use the Power of Command Shells
tips.text: Use the shell when graphical user interfaces don't cut it.

tips.name: Use a Single Editor Well
tips.text: The editor should be an extension of your hand; make sure your editor is configurable, extensible, and programmable.

tips.name: Always Use Source Code Control
tips.text: Source code control is a time machine for your work, you can go back.

tips.name: Fix the Problem, Not the Blame
tips.text: It doesn't really matter whether the bug is your fault or someone else, it is still your problem, and it still needs to be fixed.

tips.name: Don't Panic When Debugging
tips.text: Take a deep breath and THINK! about what could be causing the bug.

tips.name: Don't Assume It - Prove It
tips.text: Prove your assumptions in the actual environment-- with real data and boundary conditions.

tips.name: Learn a Text Manipulation Language.
tips.text: You spend a large part of each day working with text. Why not have the computer do some of it for you?

tips.name: Write Code That Writes Code
tips.text: Code generators increase your productivity and help avoid duplication.

tips.name: You Can't Write Perfect Software
tips.text: Software can't be perfect. Protect your code and users from the inevitable errors.

tips.name: Design with Contracts
tips.text: Use contracts to document and verify that code does no more and no less than it claims to do.

tips.name: Crash Early
tips.text: A dead program normally does a lot less damage than a crippled one.

tips.name: Use Assertions to Prevent the Impossible
tips.text: Assertions validate your assumptions. Use them to protect your code from an uncertain world.

tips.name: Use Exceptions for Exceptional Problems
tips.text: Exceptions can suffer from all the readability and maintainability problems of classic spaghetti code. Reserve exceptions for exceptional things.

tips.name: Finish What You Start
tips.text: Where possible, the routine or object that allocates a resource should be responsible for deallocating it.

tips.name: Minimize Coupling Between Modules
tips.text: Avoid coupling by writing shy code and applying the Law of Demeter.

tips.name: Configure, Don't Integrate
tips.text: Implement technology choices for an application as configuration options, not through integration or engineering.

tips.name: Put Abstractions in Code, Details in Metadata
tips.text: Program for the general case, and put the specifics outside the compiled code base.

tips.name: Analyze Workflow to Improve Concurrency
tips.text: Exploit concurrency in your user's workflow.

tips.name: Design Using Services
tips.text: Design in terms of services independent, concurrent objects behind well-defined, consistent interfaces.

tips.name: Always Design for Concurrency
tips.text: Allow for concurrency, and you'll design cleaner interfaces with fewer assumptions.

tips.name: Separate Views from Models
tips.text: Gain flexibility at low cost by designing your application in terms of models and views.

tips.name: Use Blackboards to Coordinate Workflow
tips.text: Use blackboards to coordinate disparate facts and agents, while maintaining independence and isolation among participants.

tips.name: Don't Program by Coincidence
tips.text: Rely only on reliable things. Beware of accidental complexity, and don't confuse a happy coincidence with a purposeful plan.

tips.name: Estimate the Order of Your Algorithms
tips.text: Get a feel for how long things are likely to take before you write code.

tips.name: Test Your Estimates
tips.text: Mathematical analysis of algorithms doesn't tell you everything. Try timing your code in its target environment.

tips.name: Refactor Early, Refactor Often
tips.text: Just as you might weed and rearrange a garden, rewrite, rework, and re-architect code when it needs it. Fix the root of the problem.

tips.name: Design to Test
tips.text: Start thinking about testing before you write a line of code.

tips.name: Test Your Software, or Your Users Will
tips.text: Test ruthlessly. Don't make your users find bugs for you.

tips.name: Don't Use Wizard Code You Don't Understand
tips.text: Wizards can generate reams of code. Make sure you understand all of it before you incorporate it into your project.

tips.name: Don't Gather Requirements - Dig for Them
tips.text: Requirements rarely lie on the surface. They're buried deep beneath layers of assumptions, misconceptions, and politics.

tips.name: Workwith a User to Think Like a User
tips.text: It's the best way to gain insight into how the system will really be used.

tips.name: Abstractions Live Longer than Details
tips.text: Invest in the abstraction, not the implementation. Abstractions can survive the barrage of changes from different implementations and new technologies.

tips.name: Use a Project Glossary
tips.text: Create and maintain a single source of all the specific terms and vocabulary for a project.

tips.name: Don't Think Outside the Box -  Find the Box
tips.text: When faced with an impossible problem, identify the real constraints. Ask yourself: Does it have to be done this way? Does it have to be done at all?

tips.name: Start When You're Ready.
tips.text: You've been building experience all your life. Don't ignore niggling doubts.

tips.name: Some Things Are Better Done than Described
tips.text: Don't fall into the specification spiral - at some point you need to start coding.

tips.name: Don't Be a Slave to Formal Methods.
tips.text: Don't blindly adopt any technique without putting it into the context of your development practices and capabilities.

tips.name: Costly Tools Don't Produce Better Designs
tips.text: Beware of vendor hype, industry dogma, and the aura of the price tag. Judge tools on their merits.

tips.name: Organize Teams Around Functionality
tips.text: Don't separate designers from coders, testers from data modelers. Build teams the way you build code.

tips.name: Don't Use Manual Procedures
tips.text: A shell script or batch file will execute the same instructions, in the same order, time after time.

tips.name: Test Early. Test Often. Test Automatically
tips.text: Tests that run with every build are much more effective than test plans that sit on a shelf.

tips.name: Coding Ain't Done 'Til All the Tests Run
tips.text: 'Nuff said.

tips.name: Use Saboteurs to Test Your Testing
tips.text: Introduce bugs on purpose in a separate copy of the source to verify that testing will catch them.

tips.name: Test State Coverage, Not Code Coverage
tips.text: Identify and test significant program states. Just testing lines of code is not enough.

tips.name: Find Bugs Once
tips.text: Once a human tester finds a bug then it should be the last time a human tester finds that bug. Automatic tests should check for it from then on.

tips.name: English is Just a Programming Language
tips.text: Write documents as you would write code: honor the DRY principle, use metadata, MVC, automatic generation, and so on.

tips.name: Build Documentation In, Don't Bolt It On
tips.text: Documentation created separately from code is less likely to be correct and up to date.

tips.name: Gently Exceed Your Users' Expectations
tips.text: Come to understand your users' expectations, then deliver just that little bit more.

tips.name: Sign Your Work
tips.text: Craftsmen of an earlier age were proud to sign their work. You should be, too..
